channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Indonesia: AirAsia Flight 8501 Data Recorder Is Recovered
item.description: Divers retrieved one of the black boxes on Monday from the AirAsia plane that went down on Dec. 28 in the Java Sea, a major breakthrough in the slow-moving hunt to recover bodies and wreckage.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Jihadism Born in a Paris Park and Fueled in the Prison Yard
item.description: Members of the group behind last week’s deadly terror attacks became known by the name of a park where they used to work out in a neighborhood that has produced some of Europe’s most militant jihadists.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Agnes Dherbeys for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Buttes-Chaumont park in Paris where members of the network behind last week’s terror attacks used to work out when they lived in the neighborhood.

item.title: Memo From South Asia: Groundswell Chooses Democracy in Sri Lanka
item.description: In a surprise to analysts last week, Sri Lanka, which had been on a trajectory away from democracy, elected a relative unknown who promised a weaker presidency, not another king.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: In his first address as president of Sri Lanka, Maithripala Sirisena said that the country needed a human being, not a king.

item.title: Croatians Elect Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic as Their First Female President
item.description: In a tight runoff Ms. Grabar-Kitarovic beat President Ivo Josipovic, winning 50.4 percent of the votes.
item.dc:creator: By JOANNA BERENDT and JOSEPH OROVIC
item.media:description: Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic was the conservative challenger.

item.title: In Cold Political Terms, Far Right and French President Both Gain
item.description: Along with the far-right leader Marine Le Pen, François Hollande has gotten a small boost from the crisis because of his poise under pressure, but he remains the most unpopular French president since World War II.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen of the right-wing National Front at a rally on Sunday in Beaucaire, France.

item.title: Huge Show of Solidarity in Paris Against Terrorism
item.description: More than one million people marched through the French capital with world leaders, who linked arms, in a defiant rally after deadly terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: From a rooftop window, a view of the people who swarmed the Place de la République on Sunday for a rally described as the largest in modern French history.

item.title: Video Shows a Paris Gunman Declaring His Loyalty to the Islamic State
item.description: In a recording that appeared online on Sunday, two days after his death, Amedy Coulibaly appeared below the flag of the militant group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI and ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: For Jimmy Lai, Hong Kong’s Rebellious Tycoon, Next Battle May Be in Court
item.description: In the aftermath of democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong, Mr. Lai faces perhaps his greatest test, which could have bigger repercussions for the city.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:credit: Brent Lewin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jimmy Lai, the majority owner and until recently chairman of Next Media Ltd., at his Hong Kong home. He was a near daily presence at protests last year.

item.title: Disliking Kim Jong-un, and ‘The Interview’ Even More
item.description: Several democracy activists with contacts in the North said the North Koreans they spoke with reacted to the film with derision and wounded feelings over the depiction of their country.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Market Hit by Bombs Strapped to 2 Women
item.description: People were killed and 21 were wounded on Sunday when explosives attached to two young women, one of them about 15 years old, were detonated in a crowded market.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Mozambique: Contaminated Beer Kills More Than 50
item.description: Those who drank the contaminated traditional brew were attending a funeral in the region on Saturday, a health official said
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Peru: Bus Plunges Into Ravine, Killing at Least 23
item.description: A bus carrying more passengers than was permitted fell off the road into a ravine in a remote area of the Andes, killing at least 23 people and injuring 44 others, the Peruvian authorities said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Lebanon: Islamic State Group Suspected in Explosion
item.description: A double suicide attack that killed eight people at a cafe in Tripoli was carried out by the Islamic State group, the interior minister said Sunday.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Egyptian Authorities Release a Morsi Adviser
item.description: Khaled al-Qazzaz, who was the foreign relations secretary and a leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, had been held without charges for 558 days.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Resurgence of Pakistan’s Military
item.description: The constitutional amendment allowing special military courts to try suspected terrorists is a setback for democracy.
item.dc:creator: By HUMA YUSUF

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Haiti’s Economic Aftershocks
item.description: Five years after the disastrous earthquake, the country remains a global stepchild.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL E. FALLON
item.media:description: Homes under construction in Cabaret, outside Port-au-Prince.

item.title: European Central Bank Policy Makers Remain Divided on Bond Purchases
item.description: The E.C.B. is under pressure to interrupt a decline in consumer prices that could undermine corporate profits and lead to a surge in unemployment.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING

item.title: Victims of the Terror Attacks in Paris
item.description: A look at the lives of those who died in the attacks at Charlie Hebdo and elsewhere in Paris.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Kerry Lays Groundwork for Obama’s Visit to India
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry was in India on Sunday to set the stage for a visit by President Obama this month.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi at an investment conference in Mr. Modi’s home state, Gujarat. President Obama will visit India later in January.

item.title: Amid Heavy Security, 40 World Leaders Join Huge Crowds for Unity March in Paris
item.description: Forty world leaders and hundreds of thousands of people came together at the rally, watched by hundreds of troops and police officers, after a series of terrorist attacks in the city.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME
